In many ways Rush was nothing like what I expected.  When I think of driving/racing movies I think of The Transporter (2002), Fast Five (2011), Driven (2001) or Drive (2011).  While these movies vary wildly in quality (some action movies, a competitive bro flick and a one legit film), they all have VERY exciting driving scenes.  These movies also feature some aging bro-mentor meets wildcard rookie moments (Driven), intense stoic Albert Brooks and head stomping scenes (Driven), some serious jump spin kicks bringing Hong Kong cinema to America (The Transporter) and an international pec dance-off between Dwayne Johnson and Vin Diesel (Fast Five).  Sure, there are some heavy moments surrounding the driving scenes in all these movies.  But, far to the contrary, Rush's driving scenes were the least exciting scenes of the entire film...and in no way is this to the film's detriment.

Rush chronicles the ascension of James Hunt (Chris Hemsworth, deflated from his Thor role) and Niki Lauda (Daniel Brhl) from their humble Formula 3 beginnings up to the contentious glory of Formula One.  Their actions and dialogue, whether to, about or because of one another, illustrate their dependence on each other which subsequently fuels their  addiction to competition.  Each minute of this movie is every bit a duel as Rocky versus Ivan Drago and they bring out the very best (and the very worst) in each other.

But this "race car" movie hardly focuses on "action" or "racing" at all.  But it is every bit about the intensity "of" the race...and the rush experienced by its competitors.  This film is about the relationship and rivalry between of Hunt and Lauda, not the engines behind which they sit.  As such, while almost every scene is effective and elicits sneers, gasps, laughs or sympathy--none of the major action or excitement takes place while the cars are actually moving.  Quite to the contrary, the drivers rev their engines and scream around the track as Hans Zimmer's soulful score builds to something powerful.  However, the crescendo is not found in gasp-worthy maneuvers or photo finishes.  It's what happens when the cars "aren't" racing that is exciting.  The drama and humor finds us "before" setting foot in the car.  Frustrations and conflict are expressed when the cars pit.  And your greatest shock occurs not in anticipation of a crash, nor at the devastating contact of it.  No...  The heaviest moments in this film occur during the 90 seconds "after" the collision that leads to the crash and "after" the car has come to a complete stop!  Yet more intensity is found as Lauda perseveres and recovers from irrecoverable injuries driven to resume his race against Hunt for the 1976 championship.  You may not find it with the wind blowing through your hair on a sun-soaked day, but you will feel the rush and see the magnitude of the races through a different lens altogether.

But still, the cinematography does its part, seizing the drivers' hesitation with stunning rainy competition shots, speeding fish-eye lens framing and grounded POV angles.

Playing the three-time champ Lauda, Daniel Brhl masters his role as the rigid, obsessive, friendless and charmless Austrian.  His tactful brilliance oozed a preternaturally meticulous fluency of all things racing--from track to engine and from the car to the man.  Lauda's complete opposite, Chris Hemsworth champions the devilishly charming Brit, James Hunt.  Whereas Lauda remains determined, never letting his victories blur his focus, Hunt basks in international success, sexual conquest and alcoholic bliss.  It's a wonder his cause of death wasn't being crushed to death under a pile of beautiful women.  The press and the ladies alike adore this dashing silver-tongued hero.

A cameo by Natalie Dormer (Game of Thrones) swiftly ignites the screen with Hunt's sexuality.  But as the film shifts from ascension to harsh conflict, Olivia Wilde assume the role of supermodel Suzy Miller.  As Hunt's wife, however briefly and tragic their marriage, she serves as little more than an emotionless frame depicting from within the image of Hunt's downward spiral.  Serving quite a different purpose as Marlene Lauda, Alexandra Maria Lara breathes life into Niki Lauda, humanizing his otherwise coarse persona and bringing him to the realization that greater happiness can be found off the track than forever chasing the next technical victory on the horizon.  Without her, he'd never truly understand the "sacrifices" he so vehemently preaches to Hunt--or when they mount to high.

This is a film that will make you "feel."  You'll traverse most emotions of the human spectrum.  But most importantly, the start and the finish will find you feeling elated.

Any racing fan will tell you that racing is only as interesting as the rivalries between the drivers.  This should come as no surprise since rivalry prompts individual drive, forcing the competitors to be on the top of their game - with the ultimate goal of victory.  Just a few of the countless and illustrious rivalries in the world of motorsports has included both driver and manufacturer.  On the manufacturing side, there has almost always been a long standing competition between the Ford Mustang and Chevy Camaro.  Once you move on from the manufacturer rivalry, there are team rivalries, one of which is the ongoing feud between Hendrick Motorsports and Penske Racing in the Sprint Cup Series, a feud that began when the series was still known as the Winston Cup Series.  And, since we're talking about the Winston Cup Series, it's absolutely impossible to forget the rich and always entertaining feud between Dale Earnhardt and Jeff Gordon.  However, before the Earnhardt met Gordon, possibly the greatest rivalry in all of racing had already taken place - in the Formula One Series.  Of course, this rivalry - between James Hunt and Niki Lauda is the subject of the new biopic, Rush.

Hollywood legend Ron Howard (Apollo 13, Frost/Nixon, The Da Vinci Code) directs Rush, the parallel true story about Formula One race car drivers James Hunt (Chris Hemsworth) and Niki Lauda (Daniel Brhl) in the 1970s.  Hunt is a womanizing playboy, reckless behind the wheel, and egotistical to the max - but he knows how to win races.  On the flip side, Lauda is a "straight edge" driver that focuses solely on winning.  At the height of his career, Hunt first experiences Lauda as he buys his way into racing, quickly making a name for himself by winning an F1 champion - at Hunt's expense, of course.  With each passing race, the two drivers intertwine with one another more and more, often trading wins - at least until an unfortunate accident sidelines Lauda, essentially changing their relationship forever.  Olivia Wilde, Alexandra Maria Lara, and Pierfrancesco Favino also star in supporting roles.

Depending how you feel about racing and motorsports, this film has the potential to either feel like a high-octane trip down memory lane or like watching cars simply drive in a circle for two hours (the equivalent for some of watching paint dry).  Honestly, and this comes from someone that grew up during the era of Earnhardt/Gordon - it can be a bit of both.  If you're hoping for constant wreckage and fistfights between Hunt and Lauda, you're going to be massively disappointed.  That's not who these guys were, and their relationship was not as aggressive as the rivalries between Earnhardt and Gordon or the current petty fights between countless drivers all over modern motorsports.  It would be impossible to describe the relationship between Hunt and Lauda as a gentlemen's relationship, but it's not as though they hated each other either.  In fact, it would appear that they despised each other far more in this film than in real life.  However you'd describe their relationship, it was certainly entertaining and a big deal for the F1 Series.

Without a doubt, Rush is dominated by the onscreen presence of Chris Hemsworth and Daniel Brhl.  Not only do the characters portrayed in this film push one another to greatness, but these two exquisite actors also push each other, endlessly feeding thriving in their respective roles.  Hemsworth portrays a brash, borderline alcoholic that loves the limelight, while Brhl is calm, collected and ready for business.  The egos of these two characters may be on the opposite side of the spectrum in terms of how they go about their lives off the track, but on the track - there might be no better pair to mirror one another in the history of motorsports. On the outside, their relationship may have appeared to be of the tumultuous variety, but this film portrays them as men desperate to out due one another on the track.  There's a great deal of admiration for men like that.

Obviously, since Rush is centered squarely on two men, it doesn't leave a whole lot of room for supporting characters to make an impression.  This will come as disappointing news for Oliva Wilde fans, as she only briefly appears in the film - as Hunt's wife and eventual ex-wife.  Although she can be a compelling actress (based on certain roles), she isn't allotted the time to leave a meaningful impression.  However, Wilde's counterpart, Alexandra Maria Lara, portrays Niki Lauda's wife - and is present for much more emotional and engaging scenes.  Through sheer silly luck, Lara's character meets her future husband as she's leaving a party, and from there, her character is enthralled with Niki's drive and passion for racing.  The complexity of the Lauda marriage is given far more screen time, while the Hunt marriage is depicted as nothing more than a brief shame, in an attempt to give James Hunt a more acceptable public appearance.  In defense of the film's lopsidedness, James Hunt does spend much of his time womanizing rather than romancing.

For anyone that's a fan of the 1990 racing flick Days of Thunder, you might just enjoy Rush as much, possibly more - unless you have a bias for stock cars over open wheel cars.  It's brutally obvious that a comparison to Days of Thunder and Rush is not fair (based on the overall quality of the completed products), but you can't help but look at the storyline involved with each film and see some familiar parallels.  Both focus on egotistical men, followed by a tragic accident that defines the film, and finally, each flick ultimately ends in a positive nature.  The quality of acting in Rush is far more impressive than in Days of Thunder, but it's hard not to look at Rush as something more than Thor womanizing, drinking, and trying to play Tom Cruise.  This shouldn't take away from the performance of Hemsworth, but as far as the entertainment value goes, it feels like there should be an asterisk next to Rush - since it obviously came nearly 25 years later, yet still resembling a similar story.

Overall, Rush is a biopic that tells an interesting story, but does it using a plot that still feels far too familiar.  Unfortunately, the real life relationship between James Hunt and Niki Lauda was not as dramatic as it's made out to be in the film.  Still, Director Ron Howard creates a nice, free flowing film that rivals his work on his previous accolades, including Apollo 13 and A Beautiful Mind.  With quite a bit of Oscar buzz around it, the question becomes:  is Rush a serious Oscar contender?  If Rush can remain relevant despite peaking early, it should be appear to climb its way into contention.  Although a high entertainment value is present in this film, very little about it screams Academy Award.

Theatrical review.

Ron Howard, like most directors, has had his share of hits and misses.  His one previous "sports" movie was the underappreciated "Cinderella Man" from 2005.  He takes another stab with this exhilarating film which depicts the competition between two men who are polar opposites except in their desire to win.  Winning means taking the Formula 1 driving championship of 1976.

Based on real characters and real events, Chris Hemsworth ("Thor") plays British playboy James Hunt.  His nemesis is unlikeable and demanding, but determined and detailed.  Austrian driver, Niki Lauda (Daniel Bruhl, "Inglourious Basterds") is more focused on the curves of the race course than on the curves on a woman.  We see the two drivers beginning in the smaller F3 circuit.  But both are impatient.  Lauda has access to money and buys his way in to F1 with his investment.  Hunt is sponsored by British Lord Hesketh (Christian McKay), a man with money but even he has his limits.  Two women enter their lives.  Model Suzy Miller (Olivia Wilde) eventually becomes Mrs. Hunt.  And why not?  I couldn't help but think I've not seen 2 more beautiful people on screen at one time than Hemsworth and Wilde.  I digress.  By accident, the unpopular Lauda meets Marlene (Alexandra Maria Lara), a romantic partner of actor Curd Jurgens.  Marlene becomes a strong influence on Niki, eventually bringing out a more humanistic side, especially after his near fatal crash.  Suzy and James are in a crash and burn relationship of a different kind.

This movie, however is about the relationship and the competitive nature between Hunt and Lauda.  That is their one link.  Competition.  It brings out the best and the worst of each.  Hemsworth and Bruhl give terrific performances.  Howard, aided by Peter Morgan's screenplay gives cautioned insight into what makes each man tick.  It's a simple story really.  Each motivates the other.  Each wants to be the best.  Their approaches are different and they are certainly of different personalities.  Hunt is gifted, popular and loves the life that goes with the job.  For Lauda, less athletic perhaps, but uses the science of the sport and strong work ethic to become better.

Hans Zimmer adds a very good musical score to the film and the editing is first rate.  I would also be remiss if not mentioning the spectacular racing scenes shot by cinematographer Anthony Dod Mantle.  They are numerous and even for someone not particularly interesting in auto racing, exciting and spectacular.  There are never two races that seem the same, either from the way they are shot or by the racing environment.  The races shot during driving rain storms are harrowing.  Find yourself a great seat in the middle and in front of a big screen and engulf yourself with as many speakers as you can find.  It's a great ride.

If you're familiar with the 70's era Formula One rivalry between Niki Lauda and James Hunt then "Rush" may not hold too many surprises for you. My guess is, if you are familiar with the story, you are in the minority. So, Ron Howard's biographical film may have been a really great choice for a story to tell. Those in Europe may be acutely familiar with it but even they may not have heard the intricate details behind the scenes that made up one of the most bitter racing rivalries in history.

The casting of the title characters was spot on and I only know this based on the real footage of the two personalities at the end of the film and the story that was told. James Hunt was a blonde-haired playboy with a lust for testing life, partying and women. So, "Thor"'s Chris Hemsworth was a perfect fit for the part. Niki Lauda was a small perfectionist with an overbite and was played by German actor Daniel Bruhl. Combine two well cast actors with a juicy story, rivalry, fast moving cars and one of the best storytelling directors in Hollywood and "Rush" has all the right ingredients.

First and foremost, "Rush" is not "Days of Thunder" or "Fast and Furious". I was more taken by the storyline and acting than I was the racing sequences. I found the racing sequences to be a little disappointing for the most part. They were few and far between and much of what made Niki Lauda and James Hunt despise each other so much was because of what happened between them on the race track. This was all portrayed, but much of what made "Rush" a good movie was as I stated before; Ron Howard, being a great storyteller.

Not having the slightest idea of what happened between Hunt and Lauda, I found myself completely involved in their conflicted and conflicting personalities. The 1976 Formula One season was a life changer for both men and that is what the movie focuses on; one year, one season of their lives. I would only recommend that you go to see "Rush" for the story and the drama because if you're going to be dazzled by dynamic racing sequences, you'll be disappointed. To me, this was the weakest part of the film, but fortunately there was an amazing story to tell about the human spirit, the value of life and the risks that race car drivers take when they get behind the wheel for the sake of sport and fame.

"Rush" (2013 release; 122 min.) portrays the rivalry between legendary Austrian F1 driver Niki Lauda, and British driver James Hunt. As the movie opens, we see how both Luda and Hunt are rejected by their own families when they choose to become a professional race car driver, yet both persevere and manage to break through. Their rivalry starts at the F3 level (call it the minor leagues of F1 racing) in 1970. It is not long before we see them competing at the highest level, and it all leads to the 1976 season, where things would come to a head. To tell you much more would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first and foremost, director Ron Howard deserves a ton of credit for faithfully and painstakingly recreating what life was like in Europe in the early 70s, both on the race track and off the race track. I mean, it is spot-on. Howard also manages to overcome the challenge of how to bring a riveting sports movie when you already know how it all ends (maybe not so much in the US, where interest in and audiences for F1 racing are not nearly as big as the rest of the world). Second, the lead actors Chris Hemsworth as James Hunt and Daniel Brhl as Niki Lauda are terrific. I am floored to see that only Hemsworth (as Hunt) is on the DVD jacket of this movie, as it is as much the story of Lauda, if not more so, than Hunt's. Apart from these two, there are several smaller roles that are worth noting, none more so that Olivier Wilde as Hunt's girlfriend/eventual wife. There is also a very nice soundtrack for this movie, including the original score (by veteran Hans Zimmer), but also plenty of early 70s music which you will immediately recognize if you grew up in that era (such as Mud's Dyna-Mite, Slade's We're All Crazy Now, Thin Lizzy's The Rocker, etc).

Can this movie appeal to a large US audience that is not necessarily interested in or familiar with Formula One racing from 40 years ago?  I am not your typical US movie goer, as I grew up in Belgium and seeing this movie was like being transported back in time. I turned 16 on the very day of the Nrburgrin accident (I will never forget that). That said, I was (pleasantly) surprised that the screening I saw this at today here in Cincinnati was packed! On top of that, there was applause from the audience when the end credits started to roll. I'm not sure if this is indicative of the overall box office chances but I sure hope so. If you like a riveting sports drama that will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end, you cannot go wrong with this. "Rush" is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
